I just wish that the rest of the game was as well fleshed out. Don't get me wrong, I've had fun with the game, but it feels like it should be in early access or a promotional tool to get a kick-stater going and not something being sold as a finished retail product. I've been rewarded touchdowns on successful two point conversion tries. Dropped lateral passes aren't counted as fumbles. There are some ballance issues with certain teams being pretty OP (you can easily run for 1,000 yds a game with Seattle). The A.I. throws far too many interceptions (I've had as many as 12 in a single game) and takes too many sacks (I've had as many as 39 in a single game) on higher difficulty levels.I hate having to give this a negative review. I think this is a great starting point, the dev has some really good ideas, I'd love to see him get a serious backer because with proper resources and a team he could make an amazing game, but this isn't a $20 product. 												Finally an American football game on Steam! And yet, this review, at best, is a neutral review.Don't get me wrong, it can be entertaining! And I dont regret the purchase. And the dev is great! Very friendly, and seems really dedicated to the game. Its just so....lacking. Literally. I'll list the cons first, then the pros, to end the review on a good note!The season mode feels so basic. There is no stats, schedule, nothing. In fact, it feels more like it just randomly generates a matchup to play after each game played. To show what I mean by generating a matchup after each game, this is an experience I had in my season. I was the New England Volunteers( New England Patriots, fyi) and I had to play the New Orleans Crusaders( New Orleans Saints.) I played them as the road team, on, Week 4. On Week 6, I again played the Crusaders, in the Crusaders stadium. The endzones had the Crusaders name in both games. One was played in clear weather, the next in the rain. Next, the playbooks. Ok I love to strategize about football. One thing I love about Madden video games, is to look at the playbooks to see all the different plays, formations, etc. Axis football, instead has a tiny playbook. I counted the plays. Offensively, there is 45 plays, counting Speacial Teams plays. There are 45 defensive plays, counting the special teams, again. Not much variety. The game is broke down into two(2) 5 minute halves. With limited plays, you'll probably use the same play anywhere between 5-20 times A GAME. For me, most second halves are dull. But, hey, thats just me. Just needed to point it out.The Ai needs a whole new overhaul. Really.There isn't probably, a game that you dont eventually know how to defeat and counter the Ai. But this, this Ai is so simple and easy to beat. Even on the hardest setting, I still won and even earned an achievement from it! In this case, it was for the Comeback Kids achievement. Gotta overcome a 21+ halftime deficit. Even on the hardest possible difficulty, I  had to goof off for the first half, just to ensure the Ai was ahead by 21+ points. I won 36-35, even with the clock bugging out, and not stopping when it should have! On another football game, I would've lost. On Axis Football 2015, I dont think its possible for the Ai to win, unless you play horribly, or your team's ratings are lower than the Ai, but thats still winnable.Next the price. For what they're asking for it, this game lacks in. I bought the game during the promo sale, with 10% off. The game is not worth $20. Given the current state its in, 5-7 bucks is its worth at max. Maybe $10 since its the only one on Steam. Bugs abound, but none seem to be game-breaking, thankfully. How many times has the playbook glitched after an interception, or kickoff, showing offensive plays, when Im on defense? Its super annoying. And, the worst case of it struck AFTER 1.4 came out! Most of the second half for me, I was stuck using my Nickel formation, since every other formation showed my offensive playbook. Still won, and not game breaking, but still.I'll now list the few pros:Creative take on the team names.A step up from Backyard football.Good dev, even if experience is a little lacking.Final thoughts.Not a bad game, not a great game. Way too easy, even with the new passing mechanic. The game also lacks way to much in game modes. Not even a practice mode(greatly needed) kicking game is wild, and even the roster modding seems to have gotten off to a rocky start, according to some comments in the community hub.The store page says this is a great alternative to playing Madden. Playing this, it greatly increases my desire to dig out any of my Madden games and play them. Or any of my other football games, for that matter, though none are on the PC and obviously not on Steam.The dev also says hes in this for the long haul. However, its already been noted that next year, Axis Football 2016 will be available for purchase, so its up to you to decide if the long haul means this game, or if whether in a few years Madden will have a rival football game to compete with. Actually, I believe when I saw game play of this game, it was on Axis Football 2014, so it would seem each year equals a new release, with, presumably, more game modes, etc.The achievements are also easy to achieve. My first game with 100% achievements, and I earned them all in 9.0 hours of gameplay exactly, according to Steam.There are plenty of cons, yes. But, I still recommend to at least try it out. If anything, you can learn about the game of football. Or experience a decent dev. Or relive the early days of football video games.

												This may be the only football game on steam to date. Is it the greatest? No. Does it provide the basic elements of football? To an extremely basic extent. Does it have local co-op to justify a purchase? Yes, at a price. Is this a game of football you can enjoy for at least a bit? Yes.Axis Football 2015 could have maybe been quite the miniature football game. Though simplistic in nature, the game does provide for an arcade experience. I absolutely love how they made throws possible (even though it is supposed to be done with a keyboard, a game pad works just as well). Holding down "throw" will bring up a circle in the middle of the field just above the touch line. This white circle can be moved towards any player you wish. Alternatively, you can press Y to zoom out and see which player is assigned which button (such as RB, B, A etc...). The players catching ability varies and some players will actually fumble the ball if their not on a proper path to catching it. The game play itself is relatively smooth and decent, but it's the specifics where this game lacks. Take tackling for instance, there is no specific button to tackle. You simply run into another individual to take them down. This bothers me the most as the timing of a tackle and where a player makes contact with another players is extremely important. Furthermore, there is no sprint button. I'd like to assume all players run as fast as they can but having that little feature can get anyone out of a tight spot. Another issue : there isn't anyway to incorporate tricks or moves around opponents. Off a kick-off, your player will receive the ball. A second or two later, you'll notice every moves as if it's Play Action Football for the original GameBoy. Instead of spreading out, everyone forms into a cone, then into a line to make their tackle. Sometimes it'll be easy to bypass the entire team while other times you'll have the ENTIRE team chasing you. On defense, you are able to move some of the defensive lines around. On offense, there are ample amount of plays to choose from which are actually quite decent. There is a seasons mode but it is nothing extremely substantial. Some players may find the halves a bit too long. The visuals are not bad but the crowd is horrible. The sound is at best decent and the announcer is okay. Extremely neutral on this topic as some of the yelling from the players is nice. Although, they just end up standing there like pylons with no attitude after a play. The menu may be a bit difficult to navigate at first as the player may have no idea how to. You really need to pay attention to what the screen is telling you as pressing start simply won't stop the game. Although the game does a good knockoff teams of NFL teams, it just doesn't hit the spot when it comes to a proper game of (American) football. This game, more or less, is for someone who would like a football game on their library list and have a bit of a breakaway from traditional gaming. It has it's moments where it will entrap you. Soon enough, you'll be wanting more and Axis simply cannot deliver it.Definitely not worth $17 but on a sale under $5... probably.RATING : 6.1/10Gameplay C+ Story / Campaign C Visuals / User Interface C- Sounds / Music C- Replay-ability C Overall  CScreenShots : My absolute (and probably) only favorite feature in the game Don't get too crazy with your plays and drive the crowd wild Field goals are at best, OK I always choose any play that has to do with a hail mary in any football game

												I've had an itch for over 15 years that I cannot scratch. An itch to play a decent football game on the PC. When the original Front Page Sports football faded away many years ago, I thought that some other title would carry on the torch. It just didn't happen.Now we have this entry. We are instructed by other reviewers not to compare this to Madden. Unfortunately however this is exactly what this game tries to be, an "arcady" twitch game. Since this game cannot compete on this level with the aforementioned game, one would expect other areas to be better developed, but sadly this is not the case. If this game had tried to be more of a Front Office football with graphics, it would have fared much better.There is simply no simulation value to this game whatsoever. There is a "coach" mode, but this is simply the same game only you do not control one of the players. Since this game is all about action, this mode makes no sense. The action itself is not very satisfying. Often, players being blocked will just stand there, not moving. You can find the one or two plays that will always work, regardless of how good or bad the team you are playing is. As an example, after 4 games, my team's rushing defence has given up negative yardage. My opponents simply cannot run the ball against my team. However, once in a while they will get off an 80+ pass play since their receivers can always outrun my defenders (again - regardless of how good or bad the opponent team is). So every team you play feels exactly like the previous team you just played, only with a different coat of paint.There's also alot of missing elements from actual football. There are no leagues or divisions. All teams are thrown into the same standings with the top 12 teams going to some sort of post season play. There are no quarters in games, only 2 five minute halves and there is no changing this. Stat enthusiasts will be very dissapointed as there are no league leader displays. While in a game, you can see the stats of your individual players, but outside of a game, all you can do is view team totals.If you want to support one of the only options in PC football, then by all means do so.  I wished I hadn't however. We do have a very large hole in the PC Football genre, but this offering does nothing to scratch that football itch. If I enter a fruit cake into the county fair, and my entry is the only entry in the fruit cake division, of course I'll win the medal, but that doesn't mean it's a good fruitcake. 												-Most important..: This is *not* a simulation; it is an arcade game, where you control the QB /ball carrier on offense, and a key player on defense; each "half" is 5 minutes in (more or less) real time.  Moreover, while you can control a player using the direction keys, there are no special moves (e.g. juke, stiff arm, hard tacklee, etc.) a la Madden.---There are no NFL teams, despite marketing to the contrary....I played the 'Green Bay "IceMen"---On offense, there is limited play selection; without the ability to design routes, the selection is actually rather limited.   There are an impressive number of defense plays available, based on the number of linemen you put up front.---The clock/clock management is a mess (no hurry up, each play takes only a few seconds off the clock,)---since it is an arcade type game, there are waaaaay too many big plays---it's all sacks, interceptions, bombs and long breakaway runs....in one game, my HB had runs of 88, 49 and 38 yards---IN ONE HALF. ---Penalties...: there are none.---Fumbles...:way too few; Interceptions: way too many---Injuries: none  A few other observations:---The graphics are upgradeable, and on my high-end MacPro at maximum resolution, the animations are pretty good---There is a live announcer, although his calls are limited and quickly become repetitive,---There is a 'Season' mode, including single-game elimination Play-offs, but no career mode.---The AI is too easy to beat. There are four difficulty levels; after two "practice" games I started an entire season and went 8-1 before getting bored and giving up.---There is local multiplayer support (good) but no online MP (bad) There are so many absent or missing features I would personally consider this an early beta.  To emphasize,the game is strictly  an arcade-y experience---there is no "coaching mode" available---and so perhaps some of the missing features mentioned above are less important---but this is no Madden, and given the availability of other, better American football simulations on other platforms I can not recommend the game in its current state.  Bottom line:  the game costs about a third of what EA chareges for each Madden seasonal title, and has about the commensurate level of quality. BTW, for those people who, like me, love American football and have been yearning for a realistic and fun coaching sim. game, the best football game I have "ever" played---going back 40+ years to the board-game days of All-Pro Football, Strategy, Scrimmage; through the days of MircoLeague and Playmaker, to NFL Quarterback Club and Blitz; to the modern era and the yearly incarnations of NCAA and Madden---is "Pro Strategy Football," which is (unfortunately) still only available for the iPhone and iPad...if you have never tried it, you owe it to yourself to play it, then bug its devs. to port it to the PC.

												This reminds me of the old arcade-style games where I'd probably be spending a lot of time in. The last football game I played was on the PS1, which was NFL Gameday 99 and that was a long time ago. Never played Madden since I pretty much stopped buying consoles/console games after that. The game size does remind of me the early 00's where I used to buy it off from the store as a CD and it was the full version altogether. Anyways, on to the game itself. It has plenty of rough edges that can be fixed, I liked the way the ball can be passed but sometimes it certainly doesn't work really well as expected, so I pretty much rush than pass and it works for me in such an environment. The AI can be really challenging especially in close games since it always forces me to an overtime which really puts the pressure to play even better but sometimes I feel like it's not trying at all when it can't chase any further. The teams do remind me of how it was back then in the arcade, renamed teams that represented a city so that the developers will not have to deal with copyright issues. I did notice the team named Atlanta Hawks, it rings the same bell as the actual NBA team but I guess since it is football we can get away with it somehow. The stats are also interesting especially in Season Mode which I've recently started on, at least it does feel like how I watch it on TV.Granted, I have no first-hand knowledge/experience with football especially in my country where it's not really that well-known but on a personal level this sport is interesting and I've always wanted to play a game like this at least on the PC. I think the announcer is really funny, but perhaps a few more sentences can be added since I've pretty much kind of memorized everything he was saying. The crowd does look a bit dead probably because of how they were rendered and maybe a louder crowd would at least hide that. The announcer was talking about the ref...I don't see the ref, or maybe I'm missing something here.Anyone who wants to at play a football game on PC should get this but the caveat here is don't expect too much. This isn't Madden, it's Axis. Was it worth for me? I can say yes, because since I don't really play on consoles so I pretty much spend it here in Steam and this is pretty much the first football game I played ever since 99. Will it be worth it for someone else? Well, that depends. Try it on your own time.
